column4: guys, can someone tell me how i can make a script suitable for init.d to run a program which doesnt have an option to stop but with CTRL-Z?
i mean i run this program in terminal then when i want to stop it, i press CTRL-C
now i want to make a scipt to start this program on start-up
wouldn't it a bit weird to write a init.d script for a not demonizeable program?
i would suggest to use screen or something
what do you mean with screen?
screen is a nice program which enables you to: manage multiple consoles inside one terminal
the program i want to run on start-up is vlc to stream media
as a server?
yap..sort of like a stream server. streaming over multicast
and screen enables you to start something in a console, logout (program keeps running), login and reattach to the console session again
i would suggest you try something like this:
will that work even without logging in?
screen -d -m vlc-something
your init-scripts are run by root
so you can reattach to the session as root (or as whatever user you run screen/vlc)
i can just use the screen command in my script to run the program?
yep
ok thanks..ill have a look at that
np.. hope that helps
one more thing..how do i stop the program then? i mean the there should be a "Stop" part in my script, how do i stop the program runned by screen?
